skill.name: scientific-writing
skill.description: Core skill for the deep research and writing tool. Write scientific manuscripts in full paragraphs (never bullet points). Use two-stage process with (1) section outlines with key points using research-lookup then (2) convert to flowing prose. IMRAD structure, citations (APA/AMA/Vancouver), figures/tables, reporting guidelines (CONSORT/STROBE/PRISMA), for research papers and journal submissions.
skill.summary: Write publication-ready scientific manuscripts with IMRAD structure, proper citations, and journal-specific formatting
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown guides and LaTeX templates. All 822 static analysis findings are false positives. The scanner misclassified markdown code formatting as shell commands and LaTeX commands as cryptographic algorithms.

static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Backticks in markdown files are code formatting syntax, not Ruby/shell command execution. This skill contains only documentation files (.md, .sty, .tex) with no executable code.
The scanner misidentified LaTeX commands like \RequirePackage and \textbf as cryptographic algorithms. These are LaTeX typesetting commands in style files, not cryptographic code.
Relative file paths like ../references/ are legitimate documentation cross-references, not path traversal attacks. No file operations exist in this skill.
The scanner misclassified scientific research methodology content (research methods, literature review) as system reconnaissance. This is a scientific writing guidance skill.
Documentation URLs for external resources like journals and style guides are standard for reference documentation. No network calls are made by this skill.
Python syntax appears in documentation examples showing code samples, not as executable code. No .py files exist in this skill.

content.user_title: Write Scientific Papers with Proper Structure
content.value_statement: Writing scientific manuscripts requires careful attention to structure, citations, and journal requirements. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for IMRAD format, citation styles, figure formatting, and reporting guidelines for publication-ready research papers.
actual_capabilities: Structure manuscripts using IMRAD format (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion)
Format citations in APA, AMA, Vancouver, Chicago, and IEEE styles
Apply reporting guidelines (CONSORT, STROBE, PRISMA) for study types
Create publication-quality figures and tables with proper formatting
Generate professional reports using LaTeX style packages
Adapt manuscripts to specific journal requirements
limitations: Does not perform actual literature searches (use research-lookup skill)
Does not verify citation accuracy against databases
Does not generate actual figures (use scientific-schematics skill)

prompt_templates.title: Basic Paper Structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me structure a research paper on [topic]. Write the Introduction section using IMRAD format with flowing prose, no bullet points. Include relevant citations.

prompt_templates.title: Methods Section
prompt_templates.prompt: Write the Methods section for a [study type] study on [topic]. Include participant description, procedures, and statistical analysis approach.

prompt_templates.title: Citation Formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Convert these references to [APA/AMA/Vancouver] format: [list references]. Show both in-text citations and reference list entries.

prompt_templates.title: Reporting Guidelines
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my manuscript draft for [CONSORT/STROBE/PRISMA] compliance. Identify which items from the checklist are missing or incomplete.

best_practices: Always write in full paragraphs with flowing proseâ€”never submit bullet points in scientific manuscripts
Use the two-stage process: create outlines with key points first, then convert to complete paragraphs
Apply study-specific reporting guidelines (CONSORT, STROBE, PRISMA) before journal submission

anti_patterns: Never leave bullet points in final manuscript sections (except Methods for procedural lists)
Avoid over-interpreting results or making claims beyond what the data supports
Do not mix citation styles within a single manuscript

faq.question: What citation style should I use?
faq.answer: Check the target journal's author guidelines. AMA and Vancouver are common in medicine; APA in social sciences; IEEE in engineering.

faq.question: How do I format a graphical abstract?
faq.answer: Use scientific-schematics skill for diagrams. Typical dimensions are 1200x600px landscape orientation for journal table of contents.

faq.question: What are the main sections of a scientific paper?
faq.answer: Standard IMRAD format: Introduction, Methods, Results, and Discussion. Add Abstract and References as required front/back matter.

faq.question: How do I apply reporting guidelines?
faq.answer: CONSORT for trials, STROBE for observational studies, PRISMA for systematic reviews. Download checklists and ensure each item is addressed.

faq.question: Can I use bullet points in my manuscript?
faq.answer: Only in Methods for lists like inclusion criteria or materials. Abstract, Introduction, Results, and Discussion must be flowing prose.

faq.question: How many figures should a paper include?
faq.answer: Follow the one table/figure per 1000 words guideline. Minimum 3-5 figures for research papers with graphical abstract, methods flowchart, and results visualizations.
